metadata.case_name: Bengal Chemical & Pharmaceutical Works Limited, Calcutta v. Bengal Chemical Mazdoor Union, Calcutta

facts.text: Government of West Bengal referred dispute on increase in Dearness Allowance to Second Industrial Tribunal under s.10 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 on September 13, 1956.
Industrial Disputes (Amendment & Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1956 (36 of 1956) came into force on August 28, 1956.
Government transferred dispute from Second Industrial Tribunal to Fifth Industrial Tribunal on April 9, 1957.
Fifth Industrial Tribunal made award on August 26, 1957, published in Calcutta Gazette on September 26, 1957.
Award modified by Tribunal on November 29, 1957, and published same day.
Tribunal held rise in cost of living index; awarded increase of Rs. 7 in dearness allowance on pay scale up to Rs. 50 and Rs. 5 above Rs. 50.
Previous award by Tribunal dated April 26, 1951, confirmed by Labour Appellate Tribunal on August 30, 1951.

Parties entered agreement on September 15, 1954: 'The existing rate of D.A. will prevail unless there is a substantial change in the working class cost of living index, in which case the rate will be suitably adjusted.'
Working class cost of living index: 344.1 in August 1954, rose to 400.6 in May 1957 (rise of 56 points) per Exhibit 3.
If 1951 index taken as base, cost of living index fell in 1957.
Company filed first written statement before Tribunal without plea on s.19(6); second on December 20, 1956 raised it, but no issue raised or argument advanced before Tribunal.
Tribunal allowed 75% neutralisation of rise in cost of living index considering industry difficulties.

legal_issues.text: Whether Government order dated April 9, 1957 transferring dispute from Second to Fifth Industrial Tribunal was legal under amended Industrial Disputes Act.
Whether previous award of 1951 was terminated under s.19(6) of the Act, making present reference bad in law.
Whether there was change in circumstances since previous award to justify new award.
Whether Tribunal erred in taking rise in cost of living index from 1954-1957 instead of from 1951.
Whether Tribunal wrongly relied on Second Engineering Award of 1950 already considered in 1951 award.
Whether Tribunal applied wrong criteria in computing dearness allowance amount.

petitioner_arguments.text: Transfer order dated April 9, 1957 illegal as s.33B prospective; pending proceedings under old Act to be disposed as if amendment not passed per s.30 of Act 36/1956.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.33B, s.7A, s.30 Industrial Disputes Act; Amendments 36/1956, 18/1957

petitioner_arguments.text: Previous 1951 award not terminated under s.19(6); no notice given, so reference without jurisdiction.
No change in circumstances from 1951 to justify new award.
Wrong base for index rise: should be from 1951 award, not 1954 agreement; index fell if 1951 base.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Agreement dated Sep 15, 1954 refers to 1951 award

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal wrongly based on Second Engineering Award of 1950, already considered in 1951.
Wrong criteria in computing amount; Exhibit 3 relates only to menials, not general working class; no cross-examination or objection before Tribunal.

respondent_arguments.text: Agreement of Sep 15, 1954 self-contained; 'existing rate of D.A.' refers to date of agreement (1954), not 1951 award; substantial rise from 1954 base.

court_reasoning.text: Art.136 discretionary; interfere only if violation of natural justice, grave injustice, important industrial law principle, or exceptional circumstances. Points 2-6 do not merit interference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Limits apply at special leave and final disposal stages.

court_reasoning.text: Transfer valid post Amendment Act 18/1957 (deemed from Mar 10, 1957); s.33B applies to tribunals constituted before Mar 10, 1957; order Apr 9, 1957 within powers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.30 of 36/1956 was saving clause, not affected.

court_reasoning.text: s.19(6) plea not pressed before Tribunal; no issue raised; depends on facts not elucidated; not permitted in SC.
Agreement Sep 15, 1954 superseded 1951 award; self-contained settlement of charter of demands; 'existing rate' as on 1954 date; substantial rise from 1954.
Points 3,5,6 pure facts; Tribunal considered material, allowed 75% neutralisation considering industry/consumer impact; no interference.
Exhibit 3 not challenged before Tribunal; no cross-exam or objection; cannot make new case in SC.

holdings.text: Transfer under s.33B valid for proceedings in pre-Mar 10, 1957 tribunals post-1957 amendment.
s.19(6) plea not entertainable for first time without facts.
1954 agreement date is base for cost of living index change.
Tribunal findings on facts (change in circumstances, computation) not to be interfered with under Art.136.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pritam Singh v. The State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.136 discretionary power limits apply at special leave and disposal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hem Raj v. State of Ajmer
Sadhu Singh v. State of Pepsu

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference, termination of award, transfer of proceedings, constitution of Tribunals.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Amendment & Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1956 (36 of 1956)
Industrial Disputes (Amendment) Act, 1957 (18 of 1957)
statutes_cited.relevance: Expanded definition includes pre-Mar 10, 1957 Tribunals; deemed from Mar 10, 1957.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed Company's appeal (CA 125/58) confirming Tribunal's award on dearness allowance increase; Union's appeal (CA 164/58) not pressed. Award upheld as Tribunal acted within jurisdiction and findings on facts justified.
outcome.relief_granted: Confirmation of Tribunal award: Rs.7 DA increase up to Rs.50 pay, Rs.5 above.

key_quotes.text: "Though Art. 136 is couched in widest terms, it is necessary for this Court to exercise its discretionary jurisdiction only in cases where awards are made in violation of the principles of natural justice, causing substantial and grave injustice to parties or raises an important principle of industrial law requiring elucidation..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of SC interference under Art.136 with Tribunal awards.

key_quotes.text: "The existing rate of D. A. will prevail unless there is a substantial change in the working class cost of living index,in which case the rate will be suitably adjusted."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner
key_quotes.significance: Key clause in 1954 agreement; court held refers to 1954 date.

key_quotes.text: "We confirm the award of the Tribunal and dismiss the appeal with costs."
key_quotes.speaker: court
